				<h1 class="pageTitle">
    Exciting Changes to Scientific Program at The Liver Meeting®&nbsp;
	
<!-- AddThis Button BEGIN -->
<script type="text/javascript">var addthis_options = 'facebook, digg, delicious, linkedin, twitter, more';var addthis_exclude = 'print';</script>
<div style="margin-top:8px;">

</h1>
				<div class="pageContent">

					
    
    
    
    
    <table class="interiorPageLayout" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0">
    	<tbody><tr>
    		<td class="interiorPageLeft">
    			<div id="ctl00_PlaceHolderMain_ctl00__ControlWrapper_RichHtmlField" style="display:inline"><p><em>By Morgan Fincham, AASLD Staff</em></p>
<p><img style="border-right:1px solid;border-top:1px solid;border-left:1px solid;border-bottom:1px solid" alt="Jorge A. Bezerra, MD" hspace="5" src="/journals/PublishingImages/Newsletter%20Images/Bezerra%20resized.jpg" align="left" vspace="5" border="1">Jorge A. Bezerra, MD, is Professor of Pediatrics and staff hepatologist in the Pediatric Liver Care Center of Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center and the University of Cincinnati, where he also serves as Director of Research for the Division of Pediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology, and Nutrition and Director of the Digestive Health Center. As Secretary of AASLD’s Governing Board, Dr. Bezerra also serves as co-chair of AASLD’s Scientific Program Committee.</p>
<p>This committee develops the scientific and educational programming for AASLD's Annual Meeting and AASLD's portion of DDW®. Dr. Bezerra recently shared some of the activities of the Scientific Program Committee and what meeting attendees can look forward to.</p>
<p>“The Scientific Program Committee always has in mind the venue of the meeting,” Dr. Bezerra begins. “We are very excited to be in Boston again this year, a city that brings quite a bit of convenience to meeting participants.” The Scientific Program is carefully designed by a committee of experts to highlight new discoveries that are relevant to patient care and to the science of hepatology. “It is with this goal in mind,” Dr. Bezerra announces, “that we review the abstracts and select the best for presentation. This year we developed, in addition to the standard program, exciting new features for The Liver Meeting® 2010.” </p>
<p>“This is a very special year for AASLD—its 60th anniversary,” Dr. Bezerra enthuses. “It is also the 60th anniversary of the NIDDK. Thus, the postgraduate course was developed to feature viral hepatitis, the most prevalent problem in liver disease worldwide.” Six decades of progress and promises for the future will be presented in this course.</p>
<p>“The Scientific Program Committee is very excited to feature a special NIH <a title="" href="/lm/attendees/Pages/registration.aspx"><img style="border-right:0px solid;border-top:0px solid;border-left:0px solid;border-bottom:0px solid" hspace="5" src="/journals/PublishingImages/Ads/RegisterTodayshortblock.jpg" align="right" vspace="5" border="0"></a>Corner, in which Jay Hoofnagle, MD, Gyongyi Szabo, MD, and Don Rockey, MD, will chair a strong session to review key programs and the success of the Institute in playing a key role in advancing the science and practice of hepatology in the United States.”</p>
<p>In addition to the shared 60th anniversary, two new sessions are being added to this year’s meeting. “A goal of the Scientific Program Committee,” Dr. Bezerra explains, “is to take special time to discuss key issues in the practice and science of hepatology.” To this end, Emerging Trends in Imaging Liver Disease will be presented. “There have been many advances in radiological and sonographic modalities that enable a greater visualization of normal and diseased liver,” Dr. Bezerra details. “This is a good time for attendees to stop and see what is new both for the scientist and the practitioner.” The second new addition will be a special debriefing at the close of the meeting on Tuesday morning entitled Hepatitis Debrief. “This session was encouraged by the rich submission of abstracts related to viral hepatitis,” Dr. Bezerra states. “Dr. Paul Pockros will be reviewing what we just learned that is very new in the diagnosis, genetics, and treatment of viral hepatitis.”</p>
<p>“AASLD now has a global dimension.” Dr. Bezerra prides. “We work with sister organizations, like the European, Asian-Pacific, and Latin-American societies, to address problems that have global implications.” Speaker Dr. Howard Koh, Assistant Secretary for Health for the US Department of Health and Human Services will lead the Global Forum Burden of Liver Disease in the World. This year, the President’s Choice lecture will examine the recently issued Institute of Medicine report on the public health impact of viral hepatitis and liver cancer. </p>
<p>The Committee is very excited about the record number of abstracts they received. “Abstracts came from every corner of the world,” Dr. Bezerra marvels. “We have breaking news in several areas of liver disease from viral hepatitis to fibrosis to liver transplantation to pediatric liver disease to clinical practice.” Meeting attendees are assured very exciting new additions to The Liver Meeting® 2010 Scientific Program.<br></p></div>
